ecc-aws-283-elasticsearch_latest_version: Security > Identify > Vulnerability, patch, and version management

Using the latest version of ElasticSearch engine, you adhere to AWS best practices and receive the newest ElasticSearch features, benefit from better performance and security and get the latest bug fixes.
Without keeping the OpenSearch up-to-date, it is possible to miss out on new software features, bug fixes, security patches, and performance improvements.

The upgrade process is irreversible and can't be paused or cancelled. During an upgrade, you can't make configuration changes to the domain. Before starting an upgrade, double-check that you want to proceed. You can use these same steps to perform the pre-upgrade check without actually starting an upgrade.
If the cluster has dedicated master nodes, OpenSearch upgrades complete without downtime. Otherwise, the cluster might be unresponsive for several seconds post-upgrade while it elects a master node.

To upgrade a domain to a later version of OpenSearch or Elasticsearch:
1. Take a manual snapshot of your domain, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/managedomains-snapshots.html. This snapshot serves as a backup that you can restore on a new domain if you want to return to using the prior OpenSearch version, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/managedomains-snapshot-restore.html.
2. Go to https://aws.amazon.com and choose 'Sign In to the Console'.
3. Under 'Analytics', choose 'Amazon OpenSearch Service'.
4. In the navigation pane, under 'Domains', choose the domain that you want to upgrade.
5. Choose 'Actions' and 'Upgrade'.
6. Select the version to upgrade to. If you're upgrading to an OpenSearch version, the 'Enable compatibility mode' option appears. If you enable this setting, OpenSearch reports its version as 7.10 to allow Elasticsearch OSS clients and plugins like Logstash to continue working with Amazon OpenSearch Service. You can disable this setting later.
7. Choose 'Upgrade'.
8. Check the 'Status' on the domain dashboard to monitor the status of the upgrade.

ecc-aws-472-autoscaling_launchconfig_req:

ecc-aws-364-autoscaling_launch_config_pu: Security > Protect > Secure network configuration > Resources not publicly accessible

A public IPv4 address is an IP address that is reachable from the internet. If you create launch configuration with a public IP address, then your EC2 instance is reachable from the internet.
A private IPv4 address is an IP address that is not reachable from the internet. You can use private IPv4 addresses for communication between EC2 instances in the same VPC or in your connected private network.

Instances with a public IP address could potentially be compromised, and an attacker could gain anonymous access to the instance and other resources connected to this instance. This can lead to malicious activity that affects sensitive data.

Note: Affected resource must be redeployed to mitigate the issue.

To disable automatic ip association, create new launch configuration:

4. Additional configuration, click on the Advanced details.

6. Create configuration.

ecc-aws-306-postgresql_log_executor_stat: The PostgreSQL executor is responsible for executing the plan handed over by the PostgreSQL planner. The executor processes the plan recursively to extract the required set of rows. The 'log_executor_stats' flag controls the inclusion of PostgreSQL executor performance statistics in the PostgreSQL logs for each query.

The 'log_executor_stats' flag enables a crude profiling method for logging PostgreSQL executor performance statistics which even though can be useful for troubleshooting, it may increase the amount of logs significantly and have performance overhead.

1. Open the Amazon RDS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/rds/

ecc-aws-303-cloudtrail_logs_management_e:
Management events provide visibility into management operations that are performed on resources in your AWS account. These are also known as control plane operations. Example management events include: Configuring security (for example, IAM AttachRolePolicy API operations), Registering devices (for example, Amazon EC2 CreateDefaultVpc API operations), Configuring rules for routing data (for example, Amazon EC2 CreateSubnet API operations), Setting up logging (for example, AWS CloudTrail CreateTrail API operations).
Management events can also include non-API events that occur in your account. For example, when a user logs in to your account, CloudTrail logs the ConsoleLogin event.
If security critical information is not recorded, there will be no trail for forensic analysis, and discovering the cause of problems or the source of attacks may become more difficult or impossible.

To enable Management events for all CloudTrail trails available within your AWS account, perform the following: 
  1. Open the Amazon CloudTrail console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudtrail/. 
  2. In the navigation pane, choose Trails.
  3. Choose the trail that you want to reconfigure.
  4. Click the Edit button, next to the Management events section.
  5. Choose if you want your trail to log Read events, Write events, or both.
  6. Click Save to apply the changes and save the trail configuration.
ecc-aws-143-bucket_object-level_logging_: CIS Amazon Web Services Foundations Benchmark v3.0.0

This rule checks whether at least one multi-Region AWS CloudTrail trail exists that has logging turned on and records write-only or all types of data events for Amazon S3 buckets. The rule fails if there isn't at least one trail that meets all these criteria.
S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject, are referred to as data events. By default, CloudTrail trails do not log data events, so it is recommended to enable object-level logging for S3 buckets.
Enabling object-level logging will help you meet data compliance requirements within your organization, perform comprehensive security analyses, monitor specific patterns of user behavior in your AWS account, or take immediate actions on any object-level API activity within your S3 buckets using Amazon CloudWatch Events.
Enabling logging for these object-level events may significantly increase the number of events logged and may incur additional costs.

With disabled object-level logging for WRITE access, you are missing the opportunity to perform comprehensive security analysis, monitor specific patterns of user behavior in AWS account, or take immediate actions on any object-level API activity within S3 Buckets using Amazon CloudWatch Events. This can lead to undetected write or delete requests within the S3 bucket with sensitive data.

Trails created using the console are multi-Region by default.
To enable object-level logging for S3 buckets from Console:
  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the CloudTrail console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudtrail/.
  2. On the CloudTrail service home page, the 'Trails' page, or the 'Trails' section of the 'Dashboard' page, choose 'Create trail'.
  3. On the 'Create Trail' page, for 'Trail name', type a name for your trail.
  4. Specify the S3 bucket name for 'Storage location'.
  5. Specify the AWS KMS alias under the 'Log file SSE-KMS encryption' section, or create a new key.
  6. Ensure to make any other necessary configurations as required.
  7. Choose 'Next'.
  8. On the 'Choose log events' page, enable 'Data events'.
  9. In 'Data events' section, for 'Data event type' select 'S3'.
  10. For 'Log selector template' select 'Log all events' or 'Log only write events'.
  11. Choose 'Next'.
  12. On the 'Review and create' page, review your choices. When you are ready to create the trail, choose 'Create trail'.
  13. The new trail appears on the 'Trails' page. In about 5 minutes, CloudTrail publishes log files that show the AWS API calls made in your account. You can see the log files in the S3 bucket that you specified.

From Command Line:
  1. To enable object-level data events logging for S3 buckets within your AWS account, run 'put-event-selectors' command using the name of the trail that you want to reconfigure as identifier:
  aws cloudtrail put-event-selectors --region <region-name> --trail-name <trail-name> --event-selectors '[{ "ReadWriteType": "WriteOnly", "IncludeManagementEvents":true, "DataResources": [{ "Type": "AWS::S3::Object", "Values": ["arn:aws:s3"] }] }]'
  2. The command output will be the object-level event trail configuration.

For more information, see 'Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects' in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/enable-cloudtrail-logging-for-s3.html.

ecc-aws-009-iam_ssl_or_tls_certificates_: Security > Protect > Key, Secrets, and Certificate management
Ensure that SSL/TLS certificates stored in AWS IAM are renewed one week before expiry.

ecc-aws-062-security_group_ingress_is_re: CIS Amazon Web Services Foundations Benchmark v3.0.0
Security > Protect > Secure network configuration > Security group configuration

Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress and egress network traffic to AWS resources. 
It is recommended that no security group allows unrestricted ingress access to remote server administration ports, such as SSH to port 22 and RDP to port 3389.

Exposing port 22 (SSH) to public access can increase opportunities for malicious activities such as unauthorized access, Man-In-The-Middle attacks (MITM), and brute-force attacks that raise the risk of resource compromising.

You can enable Multi-AZ only on Redis (cluster mode disabled) clusters that have at least one available read replica. 
Clusters without read replicas do not provide high availability or fault tolerance.

When an ElastiCache is not configured for multiple Availability Zones and in case of any issue with the Availability Zone, elasticache will not be reachable. 
Multi-AZ deployments allow you to automate failover.

Enabling Multi-AZ on an existing cluster:

ecc-aws-487-codepipeline_s3_artifact_buc: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data at rest

If you do not specify a Customer managed key when creating your environment, Amazon CodePipeline uses its AWS owned key for data encryption on your environment.
When you create and use your own KMS CMK customer-managed keys to protect the data on your environment, you obtain full control over who can use the CMK keys and access the encrypted data. The AWS KMS service allows you to create, rotate, disable, enable, and audit your Customer Master Keys (CMKs).
In addition, if you provide a Customer managed key, you must attach the policy statement for CloudWatch access. You must also create the Customer managed key-specific execution role.

Without a KMS CMK customer-managed key, you do not have full and granular control over who can access key that is used for encryption. If you are using the default S3 key, you cannot change or delete this AWS managed key. If you are using a customer managed key in AWS KMS to encrypt or decrypt artifacts in the S3 bucket, you can change or rotate this customer managed key as necessary.

Use AWS CLI to update encryption configuration:
aws codepipeline update-pipeline --cli-input-json file://test.json
Inside json file choose S3 as 'artifactStore'.
Inside 'encryptionKey' provide 'id' for KMS CMK key and in 'type' choose 'KMS'.
ecc-aws-349-route53_query_logging_enable: With disabled logs for the Route53, it is harder to analyze statistics, diagnose issues, detect different types of attacks.

To enable Route53 query logging:
1. Open the Amazon Route 53 Dashboard at https://console.aws.amazon.com/route53/v2/.
2. In the navigation pane, choose 'Hosted zones'.
3. Click on the Hosted zone that you want to modify.
4. Click on the 'Configure query logging'.
5. Under 'Permissions' tab and grant permissions to publish logs. 
6. Choose existing or create a new Log group.
7. CHoose 'Create'.
ecc-aws-511-clb_internet_facing: Security > Protect > Secure network configuration > Resources not publicly accessible
Check whether Amazon Classic Load Balancers are not internet facing. The rule is NON_COMPLIANT if the Scheme field is 'internet-facing' in the configuration.
Unrestricted access increases the opportunity for malicious activity such as unauthorized access, denial-of-service attacks, and loss of data.

Note: Affected resource must be redeployed to mitigate the issue.
1. Sign in to the Amazon EC2 console and access the Amazon EC2 at https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/v2.
2. Under the 'Load Balancing' click on the 'Load Balancers'.
3. Create Classic load balancer.
4. Under the 'Scheme' choose 'Internal'.
5. Create load balancer.
ecc-aws-298-sqs_encrypted_with_kms_cmk: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data at rest

When you create and use your own KMS CMK customer-managed keys to protect the contents of your SQS queue messages, you obtain full control over who can use the CMK keys and access the data encrypted within queue messages. The AWS KMS service allows you to create, rotate, disable, enable, and audit your Customer Master Keys (CMKs) for Amazon SQS.
Without a KMS CMK customer-managed key, you do not have full and granular control over who can access key that is used for encryption.

1. Navigate to https://console.aws.amazon.com/sqs/v2
2. Choose Queues.
3. Click on the reported Queue.
4. Press Edit.
5. Under Encryption, enable Server-side encryption.
6. Choose AWS Key Management Service key.
7. Choose Customer key.
ecc-aws-595-reserved_redshift_node_payme: FinOps > Reserved instances and savings plan usage

Reserved Instances provide you with significant savings on your Amazon Redshift costs compared to On-Demand Instance pricing. Reserved Instances are not physical instances, but rather a billing discount applied to the use of On-Demand Instances in your account.
A billing discount is not applied to instances in your account.
To retry a failed RI payment, contact AWS Support: https://console.aws.amazon.com/support.
ecc-aws-202-rds_oracle_logging_enabled:
Amazon RDS, Oracle database engine logs (Alert, Audit, Trace, Listener) should be enabled and sent to CloudWatch.
Database logging provides detailed records of requests made to RDS. Database logs can assist with security and access audits and can help to diagnose availability issues.
With disabled logs for the database, it is harder to analyze statistics, diagnose issues, detect different types of attacks, and retain data for regulatory or legal purposes.

Open the Amazon RDS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/rds/.
1. In the navigation pane, choose Databases.
2. Choose the DB instance that you want to modify.
3. Choose Modify.
4. Under Log exports, choose Alert, Audit, Trace and Listener log types to start publishing to CloudWatch Logs.
5. Log exports is available only for database engine versions that support publishing to CloudWatch Logs.
6. Choose Continue. Then on the summary page, choose Modify DB Instance.
ecc-aws-402-dms_without_tag_information: This policy identifies the DMS instances that do not have any Tags. Tags can be used for easy identification and search.

Without a tagging schema, it is harder to organize resources available within your AWS environment. As your AWS environment is becoming more and more complex, it requires better management strategies.

1. Sign in to the AWS Admin Console and access the Amazon DMS at https://console.aws.amazon.com/dms/v2.
2. Click on the required instance.
3. Open 'Tags' and click on the 'Add'.
4. Add new tag and save.
ecc-aws-280-elasticsearch_encrypted_with: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data at rest

If you do not specify a Customer managed key when creating your environment, Amazon OpenSearch uses its AWS owned key for data encryption on your environment.
When you create and use your own KMS CMK customer-managed keys to protect the data on your environment, you obtain full control over who can use the CMK keys and access the encrypted data. The AWS KMS service allows you to create, rotate, disable, enable, and audit your Customer Master Keys (CMKs).
In addition, if you provide a Customer managed key, you must attach the policy statement for CloudWatch access. You must also create the Customer managed key-specific execution role.
Without a KMS CMK customer-managed key, you do not have full and granular control over who can access key that is used for encryption.

Note: Affected resource must be redeployed to mitigate the issue.

If encryption of data at rest is not enabled at all, perform the following actions:
1. Open the domain in the AWS console, then choose Actions and Edit security configuration.
2. Under Encryption, select Enable encryption of data at rest.
3. Choose an AWS KMS key to use, then choose Save changes.

If encryption of data at rest is already enabled with AWS-managed key, you have to create a new domain with KMS CMS:
1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon OpenSearch console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/esv3
2. In the navigation pane, under Domains, click on the 'Create domain'.
3. Under 'Choose an AWS KMS key', click on the 'Choose A different key'.
4. Choose existing key or create a new one.
6. Create domain.
ecc-aws-008-iam_ssl_or_tls_certificates_: Security > Protect > Key, Secrets, and Certificate management
Ensure that SSL/TLS certificates stored in AWS IAM are renewed one month before expiry.
SSL/TLS certificates not renewed prior to their expiration date become invalid, and the communication between a client and an AWS resource that implements the certificates is no longer secure.

From AWS CLI: 
aws iam upload-server-certificate --server-certificate-name ExampleCertificate --certificate-body file://Certificate.pem --certificate-chain file://CertificateChain.pem --private-key file://PrivateKey.pem --tags '{"Key": "ExampleKey", "Value": "ExampleValue"}'
ecc-aws-273-documentdb_logging_enabled:
Amazon DocumentDB engine logs (Audit, Profiler) should be enabled and sent to CloudWatch.
RDS cluster logging provides detailed records of requests made to DocumentDB. DocumentDB cluster logs can assist with security and access audits and can help to diagnose availability issues.
With disabled logs for the DocumentDB cluster, it is harder to analyze statistics, diagnose issues, detect different types of attacks, and retain data for regulatory or legal purposes.

To change Cluster settings:
1. Open the DocumentDB console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/docdb
2. In the navigation pane, choose Clusters.
3. Choose the cluster that you want to modify.
4. Choose Modify.
5. Under Log exports, choose Audit and Profiler log types to start publishing to CloudWatch Logs.
6. Log exports is available only for database engine versions that support publishing to CloudWatch Logs.
7. Choose Continue. Then on the summary page, choose Modify immediately.

To change Parameter groups settings:
1. Open the DocumentDB console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/docdb
2. In the navigation pane, choose Parameter groups.
3. Choose and open the parameter group that you want to modify.
4. Change 'audit_logs' and 'profiler' parameters.
5. Choose Edit.
6. Change to value to enabled.
ecc-aws-073-unused_eip_should_be_removed: If an EIP is not attached to an Amazon EC2 instance, this is an indication that it is no longer in use. Unless there is a business need to retain them, you should remove unused resources to maintain an accurate inventory of system components.
Keeping unused EIPs will inflict unnecessary monthly costs and eventually can prevent from creating new EIPs because of the limit.

1. Open the Amazon EC2 console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/.
2. In the navigation pane, choose Elastic IPs. 
3. Choose the Elastic IP address, choose Actions, and then choose Release addresses. 
4. When prompted, choose Release.
ecc-aws-277-elasticsearch_slow_logs_enab:
Publishing slow logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs enables you to publish Elasticsearch slow logs from your indexing and search operations performed on ES clusters and gain insights into the performance of those operations.
You can enable slow logs to identify whether a performance issue on your cluster is being caused by particular queries or is due to changes in usage. You can then use that information to work with your users to optimize their queries or index configuration to address the problem.
Disabled Elasticsearch slow logs, making it harder to troubleshoot performance and stability issues.

1. Open the Amazon OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/esv3/.
2. Under Domains, select the domain you want to update.
3. Choose the Logs tab.
4. Under 'CloudWatch Logs', select 'Search slow logs' if it is disabled and click Enable. 
5. In 'Setup index slow logs' page select an existing log group or create a new one. 
6. Specify CloudWatch an access policy.
7. Choose Enable.
8. Repeat 5 - 7 steps to enable 'Index slow logs'.
ecc-aws-594-underutilized_rds_instance_s:
Identifying underutilized AWS RDS instance storage will lower the cost of your AWS bill. A storage considered to be underutilized when an RDS instance is older than 14 days and maximum free storage space is more than 85% of all allocated space for last 14 days.
When you have over-provisioned RDS storage, you're paying for unused resources. Although some scenarios can result in low optimization by design, you can often lower your costs by decrease allocated storage size in the configuration of your RDS instances.
Having underutilized AWS RDS instance storage will accumulate unnecessary charges in you AWS account.

To decrease storage for a DB instance:
1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon RDS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/rds/.
2. In the navigation pane, choose 'Databases'.
3. Choose the DB instance that you want to modify.
4. Choose 'Modify'.
5. Enter a new value for 'Allocated storage'. It must be lower than the current value. 
6. Choose 'Continue' to move to the next screen.
7. Choose 'Apply immediately' in the 'Scheduling of modifications' section to apply the storage changes to the DB instance immediately. Or choose 'Apply during the next scheduled maintenance window' to apply the changes during the next maintenance window.
8. When the settings are as you want them, choose 'Modify DB instance'.
ecc-aws-267-elasticache_encrypted_in_tra: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data in transit

To help keep your data secure, Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon EC2 provide mechanisms to guard against unauthorized access of your data on the server. 
By providing in-transit encryption capability, ElastiCache gives you a tool you can use to help protect your data when it is moving from one location to another.

Without enabled encryption in transit, ElastiCache cluster accepts a connection whether it uses SSL or not. This can lead to malicious activity such as man-in-the-middle attacks (MITM), intercepting, or manipulating network traffic.

Enabling in-transit encryption for an existing Redis cluster using the AWS Management Console:
Step 1: Set your Transit encryption mode to Preferred
  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon ElastiCache console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/elasticache/.
  2. Choose 'Redis clusters' from the ElastiCache 'Resources' listed on the navigation pane, present on the left hand.
  3. Choose the Redis cluster you want to update.
  4. Choose the 'Actions' dropdown, then choose 'Modify'.
  5. Choose 'Enable' under 'Encryption in transit' in the 'Security' section.
  6. Choose 'Preferred' as the 'Transit encryption mode'.
  7. Choose 'Preview changes' and save your changes.

After you migrate all your Redis clients to use encrypted connections:
Step 2: Set your Transit encryption mode to Required
  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon ElastiCache console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/elasticache/.
  2. Choose 'Redis clusters' from the ElastiCache 'Resources' listed on the navigation pane, present on the left hand.
  3. Choose the Redis cluster you want to update.
  4. Choose the 'Actions' dropdown, then choose 'Modify'.
  5. Choose 'Required' as the 'Transit encryption mode', in the 'Security' section.
  6. Choose 'Preview changes' and save your changes.

Note: Affected ElastiCache for Memcached cluster must be redeployed to mitigate the issue.
To create an ElastiCache for Memcached cluster with encryption in-transit enabled:
1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the ElastiCache console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/elasticache/.
2. From the list in the upper-right corner, choose the AWS Region you want to launch this cluster in.
3. Choose 'Memcached clusters' from the navigation pane.
4. Choose 'Create Memcached cluster'.
5. Complete the 'Cluster settings' section. 
6. Click 'Next'.
7. On the 'Advanced settings' section, under 'Security', choose 'Enable' for 'Encryption in-transit'.
8. Complete the 'Advanced settings' section. 
9. Click 'Next'.
10. Review all your entries and choices, then go back and make any needed corrections. When you're ready, choose 'Create' to launch your cluster.
ecc-aws-246-transit_gateway_default_rout:
If default route table association option is enabled, all Transit Gateway attachments are automatically added to default route table.
To manage the VPC environment and the transit gateway, it is preferable to manually establish the table association for the transit gateway.

With the Default Route Table Association enabled, you have no control over which Transit Gateway Route Table you can associate Transit Gateway with, and without it you can not implement custom routing rules and routing requirements.

Perform the following steps in order to set 'Default route table association' to disable:
1. Sign in to the Amazon VPC console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/vpc/.
2. Choose Transit Gateways.
3. Choose relevant gateway and click Actions and select Modify.
4. Uncheck 'Default route table association'.
5. Update route table with the necessary routes.
ecc-aws-087-redshift_cluster_prohibit_pu: Security > Protect > Secure network configuration > Resources not publicly accessible

When Amazon Redshift clusters are publicly accessible and have a public IP address, every machine on the Internet can establish a connection to these clusters which increases the opportunity for malicious activity such as SQL injections or Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. Unless you intend to make your cluster publicly accessible, it should not be configured with public access.

When Amazon Redshift clusters are publicly accessible and have a public IP address, every machine on the Internet can establish a connection to these clusters which increases the opportunity for malicious activity such as SQL injections or Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. Unless you intend to make your cluster publicly accessible, it should not be configured with public access.

1. Open the Amazon Redshift console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/redshift/.
2. On the navigation pane, choose Clusters and then select your public Amazon Redshift cluster. 
3. From the Cluster drop-down menu, choose Modify cluster. 
4. In Publicly accessible, choose No. 
5. Choose Modify.
ecc-aws-299-cloudfront_distribution_fiel: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data at rest and in transit

Field-level encryption adds an additional layer of security that lets you protect sensitive data, such as credit card numbers or personally identifiable information (PII) like social security numbers throughout system processing so that only certain applications can see it.
When the HTTPS request with field-level encryption is forwarded to the origin, and the request is routed throughout your origin application or subsystem, the sensitive data is still encrypted, reducing the risk of a data breach or accidental data loss of the sensitive data. Components that need access to the sensitive data for business reasons, such as a payment processing system needing access to a credit number, can use the appropriate private key to decrypt and access the data.
Without field-level encryption, sensitive information could be exposed to unauthorized processes and pose a threat of data breach or accidental data loss.

To enable field-level encryption for your Amazon CloudFront web distributions, perform the following actions: 

Step 1: Create an RSA key pair
1. For example, if youre using OpenSSL, you can use the following command to generate a key pair with a length of 2048 bits and save it in the file private_key.pem: 
  'openssl genrsa -out private_key.pem 2048'
2. The resulting file contains both the public and the private key. To extract the public key from that file, run the following command:
  'openssl rsa -pubout -in private_key.pem -out public_key.pem'
  The public key file (public_key.pem) contains the encoded key value that you paste in the following step.

Step 2: Add your public key to CloudFront
After you get your RSA key pair, add your public key to CloudFront.
To add your public key to CloudFront:
1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the CloudFront console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudfront/v3/home.
2. In the navigation pane, choose Public key.
3. Choose Add public key.
4. For Key name, type a unique name for the key. The name can't have spaces and can include only alphanumeric characters, underscores (_), and hyphens (-). The maximum number of characters is 128.
5. For Key value, paste the encoded key value for your public key, including the -----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY----- and -----END PUBLIC KEY----- lines.
6. For Comment, add an optional comment. For example, you could include the expiration date for the public key.
7. Choose Add.

Step 3: Create a profile for field-level encryption
After you add at least one public key to CloudFront, create a profile that tells CloudFront which fields to encrypt.
To create a profile for field-level encryption:
1. In the navigation pane, choose Field-level encryption.
2. Choose Create profile.
3. Fill in the fields.
4. After you fill in the fields, choose Create profile.

Step 4: Create a configuration
To create a configuration for field-level encryption:
1. On the Field-level encryption page, choose Create configuration.
2. Fill in the 'Default profile ID' field to specify the profile to use. 
3. If you want to change the CloudFront default behavior for the following options, select the appropriate check box.
  a) Forward request to origin when requests content type is not configured. Select the check box if you want to allow the request to go to your origin if you have not specified a profile to use for the content type of the request.
  b) Override the profile for a content type with a provided query argument. Select the check box if you want to allow a profile provided in a query argument to override the profile that youve specified for a content type.
4. If you select the check box to allow a query argument to override the default profile, you must complete the additional fields for the configuration. 

Step 5: Add a configuration to a cache behavior
1. Go back to the navigation panel and choose Distributions. 
2. Select the distribution that you want to reconfigure.
3. Choose the Behaviors tab and select the default behavior for the distribution.
4. Click the Edit button. 
5. On the Edit Behavior page, select the ID of the field-level encryption configuration. Note that you can set the field-level encryption configuration only when Viewer Protocol Policy and Origin Protocol Policy settings are using HTTPS. 
6. Click 'Save changes'

ecc-aws-322-oracle_sql92_security_flag_e: SQL92_SECURITY specifies whether users must have been granted the SELECT object privilege in order to execute such UPDATE or DELETE statements.

A user without a SELECT privilege can still infer the value stored in a column by referring to that column in a DELETE or UPDATE statement. This setting prevents inadvertent information disclosure by ensuring that only users who already have the SELECT privilege can execute the statements that would allow them to infer the stored values.

1. Open the Amazon RDS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/rds/
2. In the navigation pane, choose Parameter groups.
3. Choose the required parameter group
4. Choose Edit parameters.
5. Under Parameters, in the search bar, type 'sql92_security'.

ecc-aws-338-sagemaker_instance_root_disa: By default, when you create a notebook instance, users that log into that notebook instance have root access.
Users with root access have administrator privileges, users can access and edit all files on a notebook instance with root access enabled.

To disable root access:
1. Open the Sagemaker console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/
2. Choose Notebook instances, and then choose the notebook instance which you want to update.
3. Choose Stop.
4. Once the status of the Notebook instance is Stopped, choose Edit.
5. In the Permissions and encryption settings disable Root access.

ecc-aws-065-encrypted_connection_between: Security > Protect > Data protection > Encryption of data in transit

Enforce HTTPS-only traffic between a CloudFront distribution and the origin. It is recommended to use HTTPS for secure communications between your CloudFront distribution and end users to guarantee encryption of traffic and prevent malicious actors from intercepting your traffic. 
Note: This rule runs on all the origins except S3 Buckets.

The unencrypted traffic between the edge servers and the custom origin can be disclosed by malicious users in case they are able to capture packets sent across Cloudfront Content Distribution Network (CDN).

Perform the following for each distribution that failed the rule: 
On the AWS CloudFront console, check the details for the distribution and ensure that the Viewer Protocol Policy is HTTPS Only. 
Configure CloudFront to require HTTPS between viewers and CloudFront. 
1. Navigate to the the AWS console CloudFront dashboard.
2. Select your distribution ID.
3. Select the 'Behaviors' tab.
4. Check the behavior you want to modify, then select Edit.
5. Select 'HTTPS Only' or 'Redirect HTTP to HTTPS' for Viewer Protocol Policy.
6. Select 'Yes', then select Edit.
ecc-aws-301-sqs_dead_letter_queue_enable:
Amazon SQS supports dead-letter queues (DLQs), which source queues can target for messages that are not processed successfully. DLQs are useful for debugging your application because you can isolate unconsumed messages to determine why processing did not succeed. For optimal performance, it is a best practice to keep the source queue and DLQ within the same AWS account and Region. Once messages are in a dead-letter queue, you can:
-  Examine logs for exceptions that might have caused messages to be moved to a dead-letter queue.
-  Analyze the contents of messages moved to the dead-letter queue to diagnose application issues.
-  Determine whether you have given your consumer sufficient time to process messages.
-  Move messages out of the dead-letter queue using dead-letter queue redrive.
Specifying a redrive policy allows you to avoid poison pills (messages that cannot be handled and will clog up your consumer) and provides a place for failed messages to be stored for further inspection.
Messages crucial to your applications pipeline may be discarded, causing loss of data. Bugs ans issues in code that produce failing messages may remain undetected.

To create a destination dead-letter SQS Queue:
1. Open the Amazon SQS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/sqs/.
2. In the navigation pane, choose 'Queues'.
3. Choose 'Create queue'.
4. For 'Type', select the same type as a source SQS queue.
5. Enter a 'Name' for your queue.
6. (Optional) The console sets default values for the queue configuration parameters.
7. For 'Redrive allow policy', choose 'Enabled'. Select one of the following: 'Allow all', 'By queue', or 'Deny all'. When choosing 'By queue', specify a list of up to 10 source queues by the Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
8. 'Dead-letter queue' setting leave 'Disabled'.
9. Choose 'Create queue'. 

To configure a dead-letter queue for an existing queue (console):
1. Open the Amazon SQS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/sqs/.
2. In the navigation pane, choose 'Queues'.
3. Select a queue and choose 'Edit'.
4. Scroll to the 'Dead-letter queue' section and choose 'Enabled'.
5. Choose the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an existing 'Dead Letter Queue' that you create on the previous step.
6. To configure the number of times that a message can be received before being sent to a dead-letter queue, set 'Maximum receives' to a value between 1 and 1,000.
7. When you finish configuring the dead-letter queue, choose 'Save'.
